Award.AwardTitle: Assessment of The Impacts of Black Carbon Emissions On Urban and Regional Air Quality and Climate: Mexico Case Study
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on the study of black carbon (BC) in the atmosphere, one of the major short-lived climate pollutants. Comprehensive multi-scale modeling studies will be conducted to assess the climate impacts of BC on urban and regional scales. Modeling studies will be applied to the Mexico City Metropolitan Area (MCMA) and evaluated using ground-, aircraft- and satellite-based measurements obtained during the NSF-sponsored 2006 MILAGRO (Megacity Initiative: Local and Global Research Observations) Campaign in the MCMA.

The objectives of the research are to: (1) evaluate the radiative impacts of BC only; (2) assess the net radiative effects of BC and co-emitted species; (3) apportion the regional radiative impact of major BC emission sources; and (4) investigate the influences of climate change on air quality and on the radiative impact of BC. The WRF-Chem model will be driven by both the National Center for Environmental Prediction (NCEP) reanalysis data and the NASA GISS-E2-R model output, and chemical initial and boundary conditions will be interpolated from the global chemical transport model MOZART-4 and GISS outputs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aerosols in the atmosphere influence not only air quality but also regional and global climate through aerosol-radiation interactions (ARI), aerosol-cloud interactions (ACI), and aerosol-photolysis interactions (API). Black carbon (BC), a major air pollutant and short-lived climate forcer formed from the incomplete combustion of biomass and fossil fuels, plays a unique and important role in the Earth?s climate system due to its strong absorption in solar radiation and constitutes the second most important contributor in climate warming forcing, only behind CO2. It is important to evaluate the BC?s radiative effect on climate at the urban and regional scales, considering its short lifetime and uneven spatial distribution of emissions, together with physical and chemical heterogeneities in the atmosphere.

 

This project is aiming to assess the inhomogeneous impacts of BC on radiation at the urban and regional scales in Mexico for the future years (2049-2051). The project teams (Molina Center, Duke University and Michigan Technological University) accomplished the objectives by using a modified version of the regional WRF-Chem model driven by NASA GISS global composition and climate model, and the anthropogenic and fire emissions developed for this project. The central region of Mexico was selected for this study because of its long-standing history of air pollution studies that provide a wealth of information appropriate for evaluating the meteorological and chemical performance of regional air quality models.

 

A high-resolution, chemically distributed, Mexican national emissions inventory for 2014 has been obtained. The corresponding emissions projections to 2049, 2050 and 2051 have also been developed. High resolution biomass burning emissions for the baseline years (2012-2014) have been generated using remote sensing-based approaches that map wildfire, agricultural and open burning sources for Mexico. Combination of the anthropogenic emissions with the open fire emissions has generated the model-ready emissions inventory used in this study, which represents a valuable emissions database for investigating the inhomogeneous impacts of BC on radiation at the urban and regional scales in Mexico.

 

A fully coupled WRF-Chem model, including ARI, ACI and API, has been developed in collaboration with the Institute of Earth Environment of Chinese Academy of Sciences. The model simulates the observed BC concentrations reasonably well in the Mexico City Metropolitan Area for the base year 2014, suggesting that the base year BC emissions were well represented in the inventory.  

 

Modeling results show that the radiative effects of BC are highly spatially and temporally heterogeneous. BC tends to have a dimming effect in the dry season but exerts either dimming or brightening effects in the wet season, depending on location, time, and weather conditions. While the direct radiative effects of BC are closely related to the column BC loading and are mainly concentrated in the BC source areas during the dry season, the semi-direct and ACI effects are more widespread and are not evidently related with the BC loading, and they are especially highly heterogeneous in the wet season, with the magnitude and sign varying in location and time. The variation of the sign and magnitude of the radiative effects are closely related to the presence of cloud, specifically, they are closely related to the change of cloud optical depth induced by BC. Although the BC-ACI effect on the top-of-atmosphere net radiation is complicated, there is a clear signal that BC-ACI net TOA effect is often a large positive forcing in the warm season.

 

The co-emitters of BC tend to exert a dimming effect on the surface SW radiation under both clear and cloudy sky conditions, and the magnitude of the effect by primary organic aerosols is comparable to that by BC. While BC from the area and mobile sources have higher impacts than other sources, the contribution from each source in the BC radiative effective is not linearly additive, suggesting possible interactions among BC from different emission sources in terms of the radiative effects.

 

Under most meteorological conditions in Mexico, the BC-API in general imposes an important dimming effect on the surface SW radiation. Furthermore, the magnitude of the BC-API is comparable to the combination of BC-ARI and BC-ACI in term of the domain average.

 

The extended WRF-Chem model has also been successfully applied to evaluate the ARI and API effect on the particulate matter (PM) pollution in North China Plain (NCP) during wintertime. ARI aggravate the severe PM pollution during haze days in the NCP, but API alleviate the PM pollution by hampering photolysis to decrease the level of atmospheric oxidants and secondary aerosol formation.

 

Scientific findings from this project have been presented at conferences and published in peer-reviewed journals, as well as communicated to relevant government officials. A postdoctoral researcher and several students from collaborating institutions were involved in the project activities and co-authored appropriate manuscripts and presentations. All data and results from this project are available for sharing with the interested scientific community.
